scientific_summary: Fear responses calm through diaphragmatic breathing, grounding, and gradual exposure that retrains threat appraisal (Barlow, 2002).

immediate.title: 5-4-3-2-1 grounding
instructions: Name 5 things you can see, 4 you can touch, 3 you can hear, 2 you can smell, and 1 you can taste.
With each item, breathe slowly and label it aloud or silently.
Finish by pressing your feet into the ground and noticing your support.

evidence.source: American Psychological Association, Anxiety Grounding Techniques, 2017
evidence.summary: Grounding reduces acute fear by shifting attention to present-oriented sensory data.

immediate.title: Coherent breathing
instructions: Breathe in for 6 seconds through the nose, letting the belly expand.
Exhale for 6 seconds through pursed lips, softening the jaw.
Repeat for 6 cycles while repeating 'I am safe in this moment'.

evidence.source: Zaccaro et al., Frontiers in Human Neuroscience, 2018
evidence.summary: Coherent breathing increases heart-rate variability and reduces fear-driven arousal.

short_term.title: Schedule the worry
instructions: Write the feared thought in one sentence.
Schedule a 10-minute 'worry window' later today to revisit it.
Tell yourself 'Not now, I have time set aside' and redirect to a neutral task.

evidence.source: Borkovec et al., Behaviour Research and Therapy, 2004
evidence.summary: Worry postponement reduces generalized fear by interrupting repetitive threat appraisal.

short_term.title: Threat reframe sheet
instructions: Describe the feared scenario and rate its likelihood 0–100%.
List objective evidence for and against the threat.
Write a more balanced prediction and one coping plan if it happened.

evidence.summary: Cognitive restructuring reduces fear intensity by correcting probability biases.

long_term.title: Exposure ladder
instructions: List five fear-provoking situations from least to most intense (SUDS scale).
Plan graded exposure starting with the least intense, repeating until anxiety drops by 50%.
Progress one rung each week, journaling coping skills used and outcomes.

evidence.summary: Systematic exposure reduces fear by disconfirming catastrophic expectations.

long_term.title: Mindful body scan
instructions: Lie or sit comfortably and move attention sequentially from toes to head.
Notice sensations without judgment, labeling tightness, warmth, or tingling.
If fear-based thoughts arise, acknowledge and return to bodily sensations.

evidence.summary: Regular body scans reduce fear reactivity and improve emotion regulation in MBSR studies.

friend_support.title: Anchor breath together
instructions: Invite your friend to mirror a 4-6 breathing pace with you while making gentle eye contact or holding hands if welcomed.
Name the bodily sensations they describe ("Your chest feels tight; let's lengthen the exhale for 6 counts").
End by naming one thing that feels safe in the present moment.

evidence.summary: Co-regulated breathing exercises between close partners reduce physiological markers of anxiety and fear.

friend_support.title: Use a grounding safety script
instructions: Guide your friend through the 5-4-3-2-1 senses practice to orient to the current environment.
After grounding, invite them to state one coping skill they trust.
Offer collaborative language ("I’m here, and we can take this one step at a time together").

evidence.source: National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Anxiety Disorders Guideline, 2022
evidence.summary: Grounding and collaborative reassurance reduce acute fear responses and prevent avoidance spirals.

self_repair.title: Name impact and offer restitution
instructions: Identify how your fearful reaction affected the other person ("When I shut down, you felt pushed away").
State what you are doing to steady yourself now (diaphragmatic breathing, therapist call).
Offer a specific plan to re-engage once your nervous system is calmer.

evidence.source: Johnson & Zuccarini, Journal of Marital and Family Therapy, 2018
evidence.summary: Acknowledging the interpersonal impact of anxiety while committing to regulation repairs attachment security.

self_repair.title: Draft a stepped exposure together
instructions: List the fearful situation that triggered the reaction and break it into 3 graded steps.
Identify what support you will request from the other person at each step (presence, check-ins).
Schedule the first manageable step within the week and set a debrief time afterward.

evidence.source: Craske et al., Behaviour Research and Therapy, 2014
evidence.summary: Shared exposure planning increases adherence and reduces fear generalization.
